knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.


# normal distribution histogram plot

x <- rnorm(50) #sample 50 values from normal distribution and store them in vector x
hist(x) #plot histogram of those values

# assign plot title and color

hist(x, main="histogram", col="sky blue")

# scatter plot
x <-rnorm(50)
y <-rnorm(50)
plot(x,y, main="scatter plot", ylab="y values", xlab="x values")

# box plot
x <-rnorm(50)
y <-rnorm(50)
boxplot(x,y, main="box plot")

# barplot of percentage values with barplot() function
perc=c(50,80,75,25)
barplot(height=perc,
names.arg=c("CpGi","exon","CpGi","exon"),
ylab="percentages", main="percentage plot!",
col=c("pink","pink","sky blue","sky blue"))

# add legend with legend() function

legend("topright", legend=c("test","control"),
fill=c("pink","sky blue"))


# combine multiple plot side by side
# simple combination with par() function
par(mfrow=c(1,2)) # mfrow=c(nrows, ncols)

# arrange plot side by side
hist(x, main="histogram", col="sky blue")
plot(x,y,main="scatter plot",
ylab="y values", xlab="x values")

# arrange plots on top of each other
par(mfrow=c(2,1))
hist(x, main="histogram", col="sky blue")
plot(x,y,main="scatter plot",
ylab="y values", xlab="x values")

# save plots

pdf("myplot.pdf", width=5, height=5)
plot(x,y)
dev.off()

# or

plot(x,y)
dev.copy(pdf,"myplot.pdf",width=7,height=5)
dev.off()
